The Phoenix Urban League
Guild will present tea based on
the theme, IL Am an American
1t will present dances and songs
of different ethnic groups in
American culture.


Jewish, African, Mexican and
Chinese plus other types of mu-
sic will be featured.


Miss Arlena Seneca. guild
president, said the annual
Friendship Tea will be held Sum-.
April 81, 8 pm. at Kendall Hall.
Central Methodist Church, 1875
N. Central. ,',,


Committee members include
Mesdames Rosalie Magee, Frank
McKibben. Charles Harlins. Nc
Fraddie Martin, Thomas Gilbert,
F. Luther, Lee DiCerbo, and Hugh
Morrison.

Guild Tea Set
SUnd uy Here

ST. LOUIS DR.. Martin Luther
King predicts increased civil
rights movements this summer
throughout the nation. More than
900 persons heard the head of the
Southern Christian Leadership
Conference. An estimated 500
waited to get in but we're unable
to enter.


He vowed activity will concen-
trate on voters registration this
summer. He said demonstrations
to increase the opening Of public
accommodations will be stepped
up, too.


DR.. King said the churches are
tagging In their part and they
should be integrated.


The civil rights leader urged
Negroes to use their vast pur-
chasing power as an effective
weapon in the civil rights cam
paign.

DR.. KING SEES
CIVIL RIGHTS


PROGRAM MOVE

NEW YORK = Bayard Rustin,
integrationist leader, attacked
the violent policies of Malcolm
K. =


He told 500 members of the
American Jewish Congress ma
tional women's division that the
Negro struggle could be won with
the combined efforts of Protes-
tants, Catholics. Jews and organ
lied labor. '>'f.e


He continued "The history and
spirit of the American Negro re-
iect the idea Of rifles, bullets and
gun clubs.


He accepted the Wise Distin-
guished Service Award for Ma
halia Jackson, gospel singer who
was unable to attend.


The award cited Miss Jackson
for service in the cause of civil
rights.

CLEVELAND = Rev. Bruce w.
Klunder, IT, white Presbyter-
ian minister and civil rights par
ticipant, was crushed to death
Tuesday during a demonstration
at a school construction site.


He was behind the bulldozer
when the operator, John White.
%, backed the machine in an
effort to avoid demonstrators in
front of him.


Witnesses said Klunder threw
himself on the ground. Three
other persons had thrown them
selves in front of the tractor.
yer and only police intervention
saved his life.


Angry crowds milled about and
fighting between them and police
officers lasted for severalhours.


Two policemen we're injured
and FL persons were arrested.


An expectant mother was hos
pitalized after she had jumped
into a four foot ditch at the build
ing site.

Minister Crushed
To Death A.


Demonstration

KANSAS CITY, Mo. - The city
ordinance forbidding racial dis
elimination In most business
places narrowly passed by l.743
votes in referendum.


Last September the city council
adopted an amendment to In
clude tavernS, amuSementS,
sports and recreation places,
stores, auditoriums, public
transportation, trade and COM
mercial schools.


Barber and beauty shops,
rooming and boarding houses and
rented apartments were ex-
cluded.

David Banks, IS, son of MIR.
and Mrs. Fred Banks, 1885 East
Wier, is the Arizona Tribune
Teen of the Week.


A freshman at South Mountain
High, David won the city ora
torical contest spoons ored by the
Optimist Clubs.


He is a member of the Careers
for Youth, Latin and Jack and
Jill clubs.


He likes to play the guitar,
draw and read.


Miss Lucille Hicks is his
speech coach.


David will compete for the state
title at Tucson later this month.

CHICAGO MIR. and Mrs. Dick
Gregory named their twin girls
in tribute of the civil rights pro-
gram.


The girls will be known are
Paula Int and Pamela Grafton.
Their middle names form the
word migration.

fist and local civil rights leader,
reported 20 persons at least
would be in tutoring groups this
summer.


The tutors would live with the
Negro families and try to help
prepare them for college en-
trance.

Mayor Milton Graham announced re Gently
the city council had agreed to bolster activ-
tiles of the Phoenix Commission on Human
Relations by hiring an eve cs4tiUe diYectOr.


During its first term of activity the city'S
human re loti0ns commission has proved
worthwhile and it has been responsible for
creating better understanding in the city.

settle seveYal problems which arose.


A paid executive dire ctOY IS needed.
but an experienced person is a must. There
IS little Uahue to employ someone Who has
neveY dealt with group relations nor city
programs Of this nature.


Funds eaYmoYked for this commits sion in
dictate that the city Of Phoenix is mootsag in
a definite and positive channel to Improve
minority groups Hte. @


1t is a0ell for Negroes to realize that Negro
problems are by no means the only minority
GROUP problems in this area. There are many
problems caused be cause Individuals speak a
different language, haze a different religious
belief or haze different coloYs Of skin.

Relations Commission must be wisely select
ed and he must quality for the position. Senti-
naenta hty nor favoYitism must not enter in the
selection If ne aOish the commission to be
more naeaning1ul and progressive.

ST. AUGUSTINE, FLA.--White
college students and teachers
plan to teach and live in Negro
neighborhoods this summer.

dent who is a special assistant to
